history.content:
For any graduate program, it is very crucial like you said to get a faculty recommendation when you apply. In fact, if you apply to the 5th years master's program, your other recommendations mean very little, and your admission basically hinges on a single faculty member who is willing to support you. Internships won't help you here. PhD programs rely on faculty recommendations even moreso.

That said, why do you think it is too late? You still have this semester and next semester to find an opportunity. If I'm not mistaken the due date for the MEng program is like January or something. I clearly can't say anything about your qualifications, but continue looking for these opportunities and there's a good chance you can find something.

children.subject:
M.Eng. is not nearly as dependent on research skills as, say, the Ph.D. program is.  If you have good industrial recommendations, you should apply to the M.Eng. program.

While it's unlikely you'd get into a top Ph.D. program without a strong faculty letter, M.Eng. is a different beast.  They're looking for people who will succeed in industry.

history.content:
I am currently a junior CS student, and I am facing the dilemma of whether I should apply for graduate school.

  I am more of an industry person, as I enjoy working on real-life projects, networking with others, making an impact to the world rather than doing academic research. However, I also would love to further my studies. After some time of researching, I found MENG program in Berkeley and in some other schools are a great fit to me. As they are more industry-oriented, only one-year and help you strengthen your skillset and knowledge. 

  However, now is near the time to apply, I find that I am lacking one crucial recommendation letter. I believe that I can successfully secure two recommendation letters from my two internship experiences. But I never once have the opportunity to do research with faculty.

  I've been keep improving my skills and applied to URAP for the past 3 consecutive semesters, and got rejected every time. I've been emailing many professors I took class with, and barely got an reply. The class in always so huge here and sometimes I have to wait in line for a long time before I can speak with a professor.

  There is only one semester left until application to graduate school. I find it impossible to find a research opportunity to get a valuable recommendation letter. I think I can find a TA who knows me well to write a letter for me. But with thousands of students applying for a program, hundreds of them with strong recommendation letters from a faculty, I find the odds of being accepted into my ideal Master program nearly zero.

   Under the circumstance, should I give up on applying to graduate school? I have a relatively strong resume and two previous internship experiences. While it is hard to get a job as soon as you graduate, maybe it's worth trying? I really need some advice to plan my future.
history.subject: Should I give up graduate school?
